data.text:
The answer to the question depends on the specific time point. Today, Alsace and (Eastern) Lorraine are clearly French lands, whereas historically, they were clearly German.

In the 9th century, the Frankish Empire was divided into an Eastern and a Western part. The area in question has been part of the Eastern Frankish Empire and the subsequent Holy Roman Empire since then, for almost eight centuries.

During this time, Alsatian cities flourished, and the region significantly contributed to and participated in the development of German culture in the 13th to the 16th centuries. Examples include Gottfried von Strassburg with his Middle High German epos Tristan (13th century), and Sebastian Brant with his satire Ship of Fools, one of the most widely read books in German before the Reformation. Strassburg was an important center for the development of a common standard German language, and it is not by accident that the first newspaper of the world was published there (Johann Carolus's Relation, 1605, in German language). It is interesting that in comparison with other humanists, those from the Alsace (e.g. Jakob Wimpfeling) showed themselves particularly patriotic.

It was not until the 17th century that the French influence became significant. When the Holy Roman Empire was weakened by the Thirty Years' War and threatened by the Ottoman Empire, France under Louis XIV started an aggressive war of expansion, with the city of Strassburg being forcibly annexed in 1681. However, the region stayed culturally and linguistically German; when Goethe studied there in the 1770s, he did so because Strassburg was still part of the German cultural sphere. This changed with the French Revolution, when the bourgeoisie in the cities started to adopt the French language, whereas the lower classes and the rural population continued to speak German.

German remained the native language of most Alsatians well into the 1960s, in spite of all Frenchification efforts. Nevertheless, the cultural and linguistic identity of the Alsatians was broken after WWII, and they were ashamed of speaking German and in great numbers decided not to pass on their linguistic heritage to their children.

Today, Alsace has completely lost its German identity and is proud to be one of the most patriotic regions of France. The Alsatians have also decided for French monolingualism; German will be extinct in the Alsace in a matter of decades.

As an absurd by-product of the historical developments, Strassburg today is one of the most typical German-looking cities, with its medieval core and the 19th century expansion (e.g. the university), whereas most larger German cities in Germany proper have been destroyed during WWII.

...

During that time(15th-16th century),Lorraine was pretty much a French country, with a full-blooded French ruling dynasty and kept strong relationships with France and Burgundy(the two powers also viewed the Duchy of Lorraine as a possible prey)

Alsace was part of the HRE, but was largely indipendent; this territory was a sort of "point of connection" between French,Burgundian,Habsburg and Swiss interests, counterbalanced by Alsace's spirit of indipendece(strongly favoured by the ecclesistical lordship and the municipal towns); the language was much more German oriented

...

It certainly makes sense to distinguish between Alsace and Lorraine. Whereas Alsace was almost completely German-speaking through most of its history, the case is different for Lorraine. Most of Lorraine was French-speaking over centuries and had a clear French identity. However, the territory in question - the one annexed to Germany - comprises only the third of Lorraine which was German-speaking. For strategic reasons, some relatively minor French-speaking parts were also annexed, in particular the Francophone city of Metz.

For the Alsace, I cannot recognize any function as a mediator between French and German culture before the French Revolution. I consider this a modern interpretation that satisfies our desire for multicultural places; it has nothing to do with reality. Strassburg in 1600 was a thoroughly German city no less than Cologne. Of course, it used to have a strong sense of independence in medieval ages, but this was very similar to other South German cities like Nuremberg or Augsburg.

In theory, it should have been possible to keep some of the German culture and language despite the integration into the French state. However, the perceived German character of the region has obviously not been viewed as an asset by the Alsatians, but rather as a burden for the full integration into the centralist and unitarian French state.

Thanks for this good explanation

France has the better claim because when conflicts erupted between France-Germany they have been predisposed to the French. The reception of the French army returning to the region upon victory in WWI made this clear to outsiders. Speaking German at whatever point in history does not make them German rather than French. French identity (since the revolution) is not dictated by ethnicity/language/religion and this goes for Germany as well since recent decades. Remember that less than 20% of the people in "France" spoke "French" during the Napoleonic era. By that logic France would have a legitimate claim on only small parts of modern France.

Delving into who spoke what language in what century as an identification of a nation is an outdated concept and one that helped ignite several bloody wars between the two nations. How Germans identified someone as German and the French identified someone as French were based upon different factors during the times between 1870-1945. The Germans embraced concepts of racial and linguistic nationalism while the French moved away from this. Germany and France from 1871-1945 really represented two opposite models of European state.

It is true that after the French Revolution, the Alsace developed an allegiance to the French state, while still retaining much of its German culture and language. This should have been respected in 1870/71, maybe by means of a referendum. The same is true, however, for 1918/19 - why were people not asked what they wanted? I am not sure about the outcome at that time; a majority towards Germany would have been a possibility.

The French have always maintained that their understanding of the state and citizenship was different from the German one; and you clearly fell for this nice assertion. In short: French nationalism was supposed to be characterized by the expressed will to be citizen of nation, while German nationalism was supposed to be based on ethnicity and language. That is of course nice in theory, but in 1918/19, the French nevertheless decided to ethnically cleanse Alsace-Lorraine, with the effect that 300,000 people had to leave the region because they were not deemed French enough. In 1870/71, no such thing occurred; people were free to choose whether they wanted to stay or to leave (only 50,000 left for France). And of course, after 1918/19, the German language was forbidden in Alsace-Lorraine, and all efforts were made to eradicate the language against the will of the people.

The ethnic cleansing and the language policy after 1918/19 clearly show that French nationalism in practice was not that different from the German one.

I had thought France first "took" Alsace and Lorriane during the reign of Louis XVI as part of the Thirty Years War.

The region that was once called Lotharingia was allways disputed betwen France and "Germany", especially Burgund and later the northern regions of Lotharingia.

The history of conquest of Alsace-Lorraine mainly started since the 30y-war, when France started to gain control over several cities and regions. In 1648 the emperor and the habsburgians relinquished all rights on their territories and those of the empire. That means, that e.g. former imperial cities with special rights were now given to france, allthough this would have meant a reduction of the rights of thes cities. Especially in the 1680th with the reunion-politics, where france demanded every territory which ever belonged to countries wihich were parts of France from the empire. A French court was responsible for this. Of course they decided in every case, that these cities and territories have to subject to France. Then France mad an ultimatum to subject and threatened with military force. It lasted till 1714 untill Austria acknowledged the situation. A further step was done during the french revolution, when other territories were annexed and as well the french nationalism led to a more rigide incorporation.

Your question involves two related aspects, which may lead people to vote differently, dependent on how they understand your question.

The first aspect concerns the present time. I think it is clear that today the territory what used to be called Alsace-Lorraine is French, and that any German claim on that territory would be utterly stupid. The people there feel as French citizens and don't want to be part of Germany or even the German cultural sphere anymore.

In the historical perspective, the situation is different, in particular before the Thirty Years' War, and probably up to the French Revolution. How things were in 1870/71 and 1918/19, we don't really know, as the people in Alsace-Lorraine were never asked about their own opinion. It is nevertheless clear that summing up a thousand years of history, the German character of the region prevailed strongly.

So the answer to your question in regard to the present would be France, in regard to history Germany.

It is true that after the French Revolution, the Alsace developed an allegiance to the French state, while still retaining much of its German culture and language. In 1870/71, no such thing occurred; people were free to choose whether they wanted to stay or to leave (only 50,000 left for France). And of course, after 1918/19, the German language was forbidden in Alsace-Lorraine, and all efforts were made to eradicate the language against the will of the people.

The ethnic cleansing and the language policy after 1918/19 clearly show that French nationalism in practice was not that different from the German one.

You certainly make an excellent point outlining the difference between French identity in theory and practice. In theory a black Frenchman would be completely equal and fully French if born in French, practiced French customs, etc - but he would certainly face discrimination and stigma of being a newcomer simply due to appearance. One could use the United States as a parallel to this example with French (in theory all Americans were "equal" long before the 1960's).

Regarding your question in the top paragraph as to why the inhabitants of Alsace and Lorraine were not put to a democratic vote as so many other regions of Europe were in 1918-1919 - according to the allied powers following the armistice, the Alsatians overwhelmingly welcomed French troops as liberators and the British, Americans, and Italians, decided that a vote would be pointless.

In my personal "real life" experience , all the Alsatians I have ever met (especially those from Strasbourg) have ardently considered themselves completely "French" when I asked them if they are "German".
